trans-unit.source: Getting Started with Microsoft Azure Service Fabric Reliable Services
trans-unit.target: Getting Started with Microsoft Azure Service Fabric Reliable Services

trans-unit.source: How to create a Service Fabric Application with stateless and stateful services.
trans-unit.target: How to create a Service Fabric Application with stateless and stateful services.

trans-unit.source: A Service Fabric Application contains one or more services that run your code.
trans-unit.target: A Service Fabric Application contains one or more services that run your code.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through the steps of creating both stateless and stateful "Hello World" Service Fabric Applications using the [Reliable Services programming model](../Service-Fabric/service-fabric-reliable-services-introduction.md).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through the steps of creating both stateless and stateful "Hello World" Service Fabric Applications using the [Reliable Services programming model](../Service-Fabric/service-fabric-reliable-services-introduction.md).

trans-unit.source: A stateless service is the type of service that mostly exists in cloud applications today.
trans-unit.target: A stateless service is the type of service that mostly exists in cloud applications today.

trans-unit.source: The service is considered stateless because the service itself does not contain data that needs to be stored reliably or made highly available - in other words, if an instance of a stateless service shuts down, all of its internal state is lost.
trans-unit.target: The service is considered stateless because the service itself does not contain data that needs to be stored reliably or made highly available - in other words, if an instance of a stateless service shuts down, all of its internal state is lost.

trans-unit.source: In these types of services, state must be persisted to an external store, such as Azure Tables or a SQL database, to be made highly-available and reliable.
trans-unit.target: In these types of services, state must be persisted to an external store, such as Azure Tables or a SQL database, to be made highly-available and reliable.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric introduces a new kind of service that is stateful: A service that can maintain state reliably within the service itself, co-located with the code that's using it.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric introduces a new kind of service that is stateful: A service that can maintain state reliably within the service itself, co-located with the code that's using it.

trans-unit.source: Your state is made highly available by Service Fabric without the need to persist state to an external store.
trans-unit.target: Your state is made highly available by Service Fabric without the need to persist state to an external store.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll implement both a stateless service and a stateful service that keeps an internal counter.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll implement both a stateless service and a stateful service that keeps an internal counter.

trans-unit.source: In the stateless service, the value of the counter is lost when the service restarts or moves.
trans-unit.target: In the stateless service, the value of the counter is lost when the service restarts or moves.

trans-unit.source: However, in the stateful service, the counter state is made reliable by Service Fabric so that if the service execution is interrupted for any reason in the middle of counting, it can pick up right where it left off.
trans-unit.target: However, in the stateful service, the counter state is made reliable by Service Fabric so that if the service execution is interrupted for any reason in the middle of counting, it can pick up right where it left off.

trans-unit.source: Let's start with a stateless service.
trans-unit.target: Let's start with a stateless service.

trans-unit.source: Launch Visual Studio 2015 RC as Administrator, and create a new Service Fabric Application Project named HelloWorld:
trans-unit.target: Launch Visual Studio 2015 RC as Administrator, and create a new Service Fabric Application Project named HelloWorld:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Use the New Project dialog to create a new Service Fabric Application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Use the New Project dialog to create a new Service Fabric Application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Then create a Stateless Service project named HelloWorldStateless:
trans-unit.target: Then create a Stateless Service project named HelloWorldStateless:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>In the second dialog, create a stateless service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>In the second dialog, create a stateless service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Your solution now contains 2 projects:
trans-unit.target: Your solution now contains 2 projects:

trans-unit.source: HelloWorld This is the application project that contains your services.
trans-unit.target: HelloWorld This is the application project that contains your services.

trans-unit.source: It also contains the application manifest that describes the application and a number of PowerShell scripts that help you to deploy your application.
trans-unit.target: It also contains the application manifest that describes the application and a number of PowerShell scripts that help you to deploy your application.

trans-unit.source: HelloWorldStateless This is the service project, which contains the stateless service implementation.
trans-unit.target: HelloWorldStateless This is the service project, which contains the stateless service implementation.

trans-unit.source: Open the HelloWorld.cs file in the service project.
trans-unit.target: Open the HelloWorld.cs file in the service project.

trans-unit.source: In Service Fabric, a service can run any business logic whatsoever.
trans-unit.target: In Service Fabric, a service can run any business logic whatsoever.

trans-unit.source: The service API provides two entry points for your code:
trans-unit.target: The service API provides two entry points for your code:

trans-unit.source: An open-ended entry point method called RunAsync where you can begin executing any workload you want, such as long-running compute workloads.
trans-unit.target: An open-ended entry point method called RunAsync where you can begin executing any workload you want, such as long-running compute workloads.

trans-unit.source: A communication entry point where you can plug in your communication stack of choice, such as Web API, where you can start receiving requests from users or other services.
trans-unit.target: A communication entry point where you can plug in your communication stack of choice, such as Web API, where you can start receiving requests from users or other services.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we will focus on the RunAsync() entry point method where you can immediately start running your code.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we will focus on the RunAsync() entry point method where you can immediately start running your code.

trans-unit.source: The project template includes an example implementation of RunAsync() that increments a rolling count.
trans-unit.target: The project template includes an example implementation of RunAsync() that increments a rolling count.

trans-unit.source: For details on working with a communication stack, check out <linkText>Getting Started with Microsoft Azure Service Fabric Web API Services with OWIN self-host</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For details on working with a communication stack, check out <linkText>Getting Started with Microsoft Azure Service Fabric Web API Services with OWIN self-host</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The platform calls this method when an instance of your service is placed and ready to execute.
trans-unit.target: The platform calls this method when an instance of your service is placed and ready to execute.

trans-unit.source: For stateless services, that simply means when the service instance is opened.
trans-unit.target: For stateless services, that simply means when the service instance is opened.

trans-unit.source: A cancellation token is provided to coordinate when your service instance needs to be closed.
trans-unit.target: A cancellation token is provided to coordinate when your service instance needs to be closed.

trans-unit.source: In Service Fabric, this open-close cycle of a service instance can occur many times over the lifetime of your service as a whole for various reasons, including:
trans-unit.target: In Service Fabric, this open-close cycle of a service instance can occur many times over the lifetime of your service as a whole for various reasons, including:

trans-unit.source: The system may move your service instances around for resource balancing.
trans-unit.target: The system may move your service instances around for resource balancing.

trans-unit.source: Faults occured within your code.
trans-unit.target: Faults occured within your code.

trans-unit.source: During application or system upgrades.
trans-unit.target: During application or system upgrades.

trans-unit.source: When the underlying hardware experiences an outage.
trans-unit.target: When the underlying hardware experiences an outage.

trans-unit.source: This orchestration is managed by the system in the interest of keeping your service highly available and properly balanced.
trans-unit.target: This orchestration is managed by the system in the interest of keeping your service highly available and properly balanced.

trans-unit.source: RunAsync() is executed in its own Task.
trans-unit.target: RunAsync() is executed in its own Task.

trans-unit.source: Note that in the code snippet above we jump right into a while loop; there is no need to schedule a separate task for your workload.
trans-unit.target: Note that in the code snippet above we jump right into a while loop; there is no need to schedule a separate task for your workload.

trans-unit.source: Cancellation of your workload is a cooperative effort orchestrated by the provided cancellation token.
trans-unit.target: Cancellation of your workload is a cooperative effort orchestrated by the provided cancellation token.

trans-unit.source: The system will wait for your task to end (either by successful completion, cancellation, or faulted) before it moves on.
trans-unit.target: The system will wait for your task to end (either by successful completion, cancellation, or faulted) before it moves on.

trans-unit.source: It is important to honor the cancellation token, finish up any work, and exit RunAsync() as quickly as possible when cancellation is requested by the system.
trans-unit.target: It is important to honor the cancellation token, finish up any work, and exit RunAsync() as quickly as possible when cancellation is requested by the system.

trans-unit.source: In the this stateless service example, the count is stored in a local variable.
trans-unit.target: In the this stateless service example, the count is stored in a local variable.

trans-unit.source: But because this is a stateless service, the value that's being stored only exists for the current lifecycle of the service instance that it's in.
trans-unit.target: But because this is a stateless service, the value that's being stored only exists for the current lifecycle of the service instance that it's in.

trans-unit.source: When the service moves or restarts, the value is lost.
trans-unit.target: When the service moves or restarts, the value is lost.

trans-unit.source: To convert our counter value from stateless to highly-available and persistent, even when the service moves or restarts, we need a stateful service.
trans-unit.target: To convert our counter value from stateless to highly-available and persistent, even when the service moves or restarts, we need a stateful service.

trans-unit.source: In the same HelloWorld application, add a new service by right-clicking on the application project and selecting New Fabric Service.
trans-unit.target: In the same HelloWorld application, add a new service by right-clicking on the application project and selecting New Fabric Service.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add a service to your Service Fabric application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add a service to your Service Fabric application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Service Fabric Stateful Service and name it "HelloWorldStateful".
trans-unit.target: Select Service Fabric Stateful Service and name it "HelloWorldStateful".

trans-unit.source: Click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Add.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Use the New Project dialog to create a new Service Fabric Stateful Service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Use the New Project dialog to create a new Service Fabric Stateful Service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Your application should now have two services: the stateless service HelloWorld and the stateful service HelloWorldStateful.
trans-unit.target: Your application should now have two services: the stateless service HelloWorld and the stateful service HelloWorldStateful.

trans-unit.source: Open HelloWorldStateful.cs in HelloWorldStateful which contains the following RunAsync method:
trans-unit.target: Open HelloWorldStateful.cs in HelloWorldStateful which contains the following RunAsync method:

trans-unit.source: A stateful service has the same entry points as a stateless service.
trans-unit.target: A stateful service has the same entry points as a stateless service.

trans-unit.source: The main difference is the availability of Reliable Collections and the State Manager.
trans-unit.target: The main difference is the availability of Reliable Collections and the State Manager.

trans-unit.source: RunAsync() in a stateful service operates similar to a stateless service, except that in a stateful service the platform performs additional work on your behalf before executing RunAsync(), such as ensuring the State Manager and Reliable Collections are ready for use.
trans-unit.target: RunAsync() in a stateful service operates similar to a stateless service, except that in a stateful service the platform performs additional work on your behalf before executing RunAsync(), such as ensuring the State Manager and Reliable Collections are ready for use.

trans-unit.source: IReliableDictionary is a dictionary implementation that lets you reliably store state in the service.
trans-unit.target: IReliableDictionary is a dictionary implementation that lets you reliably store state in the service.

trans-unit.source: This is part of Service Fabric's built-in <linkText>Reliable Collections</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This is part of Service Fabric's built-in <linkText>Reliable Collections</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: With Service Fabric and Reliable Collections, you can now store data directly in your service without the need for an external persistent store, making your data highly-available.
trans-unit.target: With Service Fabric and Reliable Collections, you can now store data directly in your service without the need for an external persistent store, making your data highly-available.

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric accomplishes this by creating and managing multiple replicas of your service for you while providing an API that abstracts away the complexities of managing those replicas and their state transitions.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric accomplishes this by creating and managing multiple replicas of your service for you while providing an API that abstracts away the complexities of managing those replicas and their state transitions.

trans-unit.source: Reliable Collections can store any .NET type - including your custom types - with a couple of caveats:
trans-unit.target: Reliable Collections can store any .NET type - including your custom types - with a couple of caveats:

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric makes your state highly-available by replicating state across nodes and storing it to local disk.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric makes your state highly-available by replicating state across nodes and storing it to local disk.

trans-unit.source: This means everything that is stored in a Reliable Collection must be serializable.
trans-unit.target: This means everything that is stored in a Reliable Collection must be serializable.

trans-unit.source: By default, Reliable Collections use <linkText>DataContract</linkText><title></title> for serialization, so it's important to make sure your types are <linkText>supported by the Data Contract Serializer</linkText><title></title> when using the default serializer.
trans-unit.target: By default, Reliable Collections use <linkText>DataContract</linkText><title></title> for serialization, so it's important to make sure your types are <linkText>supported by the Data Contract Serializer</linkText><title></title> when using the default serializer.

trans-unit.source: Objects are replicated for high-availability when you commit a transaction on a Reliable Collection.
trans-unit.target: Objects are replicated for high-availability when you commit a transaction on a Reliable Collection.

trans-unit.source: Objects stored in Reliable Collections are kept in local memory in your service, which means you have a local reference to the object.
trans-unit.target: Objects stored in Reliable Collections are kept in local memory in your service, which means you have a local reference to the object.

trans-unit.source: It is important that you do not mutate local instances of those objects without performing an update operation on the Reliable Collection in a transaction, as those changes will not be replicated automatically.
trans-unit.target: It is important that you do not mutate local instances of those objects without performing an update operation on the Reliable Collection in a transaction, as those changes will not be replicated automatically.

trans-unit.source: The StateManager takes care of managing Reliable Collections for you.
trans-unit.target: The StateManager takes care of managing Reliable Collections for you.

trans-unit.source: Simply ask the StateManager for a reliable collection by name at any time, any place in your service and it ensures you get a reference back.
trans-unit.target: Simply ask the StateManager for a reliable collection by name at any time, any place in your service and it ensures you get a reference back.

trans-unit.source: Saving references to Reliable Collection instances in class member variables or properties is not recommended, as special care must be taken to ensure the reference is set to an instance at all times in the service lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: Saving references to Reliable Collection instances in class member variables or properties is not recommended, as special care must be taken to ensure the reference is set to an instance at all times in the service lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: The StateManager handles this work for you, optimized for repeat visits.
trans-unit.target: The StateManager handles this work for you, optimized for repeat visits.

trans-unit.source: Reliable Collections have many of the same operations as their System.Collections.Generic and System.Collections.Concurrent counterparts, including LINQ.
trans-unit.target: Reliable Collections have many of the same operations as their System.Collections.Generic and System.Collections.Concurrent counterparts, including LINQ.

trans-unit.source: However, operations on Reliable Collections are asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: However, operations on Reliable Collections are asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: This is because write operations with Reliable Collections are replicated, that is, the operation is sent to other replicas of the service on different nodes for high-availability.
trans-unit.target: This is because write operations with Reliable Collections are replicated, that is, the operation is sent to other replicas of the service on different nodes for high-availability.

trans-unit.source: They also support transactional operations so you can keep state consistent between multiple Reliable Collections.
trans-unit.target: They also support transactional operations so you can keep state consistent between multiple Reliable Collections.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may dequeue a work item from a Reliable Queue, perform an operation on it, and save the result in a Reliable Dictionary, all within a single transaction.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may dequeue a work item from a Reliable Queue, perform an operation on it, and save the result in a Reliable Dictionary, all within a single transaction.

trans-unit.source: This is treated as an atomic operation, guaranteeing that either the entire operation will succeed, or none of it will - so if an error occurs after you've dequeued the item but before you could save the result, the entire transaction is rolled back and the item remains on the queue for processing.
trans-unit.target: This is treated as an atomic operation, guaranteeing that either the entire operation will succeed, or none of it will - so if an error occurs after you've dequeued the item but before you could save the result, the entire transaction is rolled back and the item remains on the queue for processing.

trans-unit.source: Back to the HelloWorld application.
trans-unit.target: Back to the HelloWorld application.

trans-unit.source: You can now build and deploy your services.
trans-unit.target: You can now build and deploy your services.

trans-unit.source: Press F5, and your application will be built and deployed to your local cluster.
trans-unit.target: Press F5, and your application will be built and deployed to your local cluster.

trans-unit.source: Once the services are running, you can see the generated ETW events in a Diagnostic Events window.
trans-unit.target: Once the services are running, you can see the generated ETW events in a Diagnostic Events window.

trans-unit.source: Note that there are events displayed from both the stateless service and the stateful service in the application.
trans-unit.target: Note that there are events displayed from both the stateless service and the stateful service in the application.

trans-unit.source: You can pause the stream by clicking the Pause button, and then examine message details by expanding a message.
trans-unit.target: You can pause the stream by clicking the Pause button, and then examine message details by expanding a message.

trans-unit.source: Before running the application, make sure you have a local development cluster running.
trans-unit.target: Before running the application, make sure you have a local development cluster running.

trans-unit.source: Check out the <linkText>Getting Started Guide</linkText><title></title> to get your local environment set up.
trans-unit.target: Check out the <linkText>Getting Started Guide</linkText><title></title> to get your local environment set up.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>View diagnostic events in Visual Studio</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>View diagnostic events in Visual Studio</linkText>
